newsitem.title: USA: Tobacco industry defense move curbed by Fla. judge.
newsitem.headline: Tobacco industry defense move curbed by Fla. judge.

text.p: A state judge sharply limited on Monday the use tobacco companies can make of Florida's history of cigarette-making in state prisons as a means of defending themselves in an anti-tobacco lawsuit.

The ruling knocking down "affirmative defenses" -- in which a defendant seeks to avoid liability by showing a plaintiff shares responsibility for harm -- came on a pre-trial motion in Florida's pioneering lawsuit seeking $1 billion or more in damages for treating state residents with smoking sicknesses.
At a hearing last month, lawyers for tobacco companies introduced documents showing Florida prisons had for two years during the 1970s made and cigarettes and sold them to inmates.
Cohen indicated in this ruling that an appeal of his decision was possible.
Edward Moss, a Miami attorney representing the tobacco companies, told Reuters he had not seen the decision but said the ruling would make defending the tobacco companies more difficult.
"It's like trying to defend yourself in a fight without your hands," Moss said.
